Consider observations (Yit, Xit) from the linear panel data model Yit = Xitβ1 + αi + λit + uit, where t = 1, ∙ ∙ ∙ , T ; i = 1, ∙ ∙ ∙ , n; and αi + λit is an unobserved individual specific time trend. How would you estimate β1(two approaches)? Answer: We can first remove the time effect and then remove the time- invariant individual effect. Let ΔYit = Yit − Yi(t−1), ΔXit = Xit − Xi(t−1), Δuit = uit − ui(t−1). Then we have ΔYit = ΔXitβ1 + λi + Δuit Next let Δ2Yit = ΔYit − ΔYi(t−1) = Yit − 2Yi(t−1) + Yi(t−2) Δ2Xit = ΔXit − ΔXi(t−1) = Xit − 2Xi(t−1) + Xi(t−2) Δ2uit = Δuit − ΔuXi(t−1) = uit − 2ui(t−1) + ui(t−2) As a result, Δ2Yit = Δ2Xitβ1 + Δ2uit Applying pooled OLS to the above equation, we have ˆβ1,SD = ∑n i=1 ∑T t=3 Δ2YitΔ2Xit ∑n i=1 ∑T t=3(Δ2Xit)2 Alternatively, we can define ΔX ∗ it = ΔXit − 1 T − 1 T∑ t=2 ΔXit ΔY ∗ it = ΔYit − 1 T − 1 T∑ t=2 ΔYit Δu∗ it = Δuit − 1 T − 1 T∑ t=2 Δuit It follows that ΔY ∗ it = ΔX ∗ itβ1 + Δu∗ it 1 Applying pooled OLS to the above equation, we have ˆβ1,F DW T = ∑n i=1 ∑T t=2 ΔY ∗ itΔX ∗ it ∑n i=1 ∑T t=2(ΔX ∗ it)2 The third method: After first differencing the data, we can then apply least square dummy variable method to the differenced data to obtain the estimator for β1, which is numerically identical to ˆβ1,F DW T . 2. Answer: Since (1 − 0.3L − 0.1L2)yt = εt, to see whether yt is weakly stationary, it suffices to check whether the the solutions to the following characteristic function 1 − 0.3z − 0.1z2 = 0 lie outside the unit circle. Now z1 = −(−0.3) + √(−0.3)2 − 4 × (−0.1) × 1 2 × (−0.1) = −5, z2 = −(−0.3) − √(−0.3)2 − 4 × (−0.1) × 1 2 × (−0.1) = 2 So |z1| = 5 > 1 and |z2| = 2 > 1. Hence yt is weakly stationary. Suppose we have the following AR(1) process yt = 2 + yt−1 + εt, where εt ∽ W N (0, 1) for all t, y0 ∽ W N (0, 1) and is independent of εt for all t, (a) Compute E(yt), V ar(yt) and Cov(yt, yt−k) for k = 1, 2. Answer: Note that yt − yt−1 = 2 + εt so (yt − yt−1) + (yt−1 − yt−2) + ∙ ∙ ∙ + (yt−k+1 − yt−k) = 2k + t∑ i=t−k+1 εi That is, yt − yt−k = 2k + t∑ i=t−k+1 εi or yt = 2k + yt−k + t∑ i=t−k+1 εi 3 So let k = t, we have yt = 2t + y0 + t∑ i=1 εi and hence E(yt) = 2t + E(y0) + t∑ i=1 E(εi) = 2t + 0 + 0 = 2t by virtue of the fact εt ∽ W N (0, 1) for all t, y0 ∽ W N (0, 1). V ar(yt) = E[yt − E(yt)]2 = E[(2t + y0 + t∑ i=1 εi) − 2t]2 = E[y0 + t∑ i=1 εt]2 = E(y2 0) + 2E[y0( t∑ i=1 εi)] + E( t∑ i=1 εi)2 = E(y2 0) + 2[E(y0)]E( t∑ i=1 εi) + t∑ i=1 E(ε2 i ) + 2 ∑ i̸=j E(εiεj) = 1 + 2 ∙ 0 + t ∙ 1 + 2 ∙ 0 = 1 + t. Cov(yt, yt−k) = Cov(2k + yt−k + t∑ i=t−k+1 εi, yt−k) = Cov(2k, yt−k) + Cov(yt−k, yt−k) + Cov( t∑ i=t−k+1 εi, yt−k) = 0 + V ar(yt−k) + Cov( t∑ i=t−k+1 εi, 2(t − k) + y0 + t−k∑ i=1 εi) = V ar(yt−k) + Cov( t∑ i=t−k+1 εi, 2(t − k)) + Cov( t∑ i=t−k+1 εi, y0) +Cov( t∑ i=t−k+1 εi, t−k∑ i=1 εi) = V ar(yt−k) + 0 + 0 + 0 = 1 + t − k Thus Cov(yt, yt−1) = t, Cov(yt, yt−2) = t − 1 4 (b) Compute the ACF ρk for k = 1, 2.
